Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above-mentioned facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan must be completed and routed in CWLM. If you desire technical assistance

acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
Section • (5) An agency shall involve the child’s parent or parents
Description and the foster parents in the development of service plans
to enable the parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the parents’ and the
foster parent’s role in assisting the agency in carrying out
the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and review
parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-
agency treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child’s family is confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not maintaining appropriate communication with
respondent parent regarding child behavioral changes and active
investigations.
Investigation Biological mother (BM) was interviewed on 8/13/2025, via
telephone. BM reported that the agency assigned foster care
worker and foster care program manager are not maintaining
appropriate communication with her regarding her child, Youth A,
and his behaviors. She reported she finds information about her
children, Youth A and Youth B, that are placed in Orchard’s care
from Foster Parent 1, where Youth A and Youth B are placed,
before the agency notifies her of anything. BM states she feels
that her input and feelings are not heard by the agency, and the
agency acts like she is invisible.
BM reported she was never notified by the agency that Youth A
has been defiant and allegedly hurt other children at his school.
She reported she found out about this information from Foster
Parent 2 when Youth A was placed with her. BM reported she has
been asking the agency constantly to notify her of changes
regarding Youth A and Youth B in which they refuse to provide or
communicate with her. BM reported she has had several
meetings with Program Manager and Foster Care Worker, and
she feels the meetings are not effective because she is not heard.
BM reported she would like to be transferred to another agency
because she feels this agency is not ensuring Youth A and Youth
2

B’s safety. When asked about the safety of Youth A and Youth B,
she explained the agency is not ensuring safety due to Youth A
being bullied and hit by Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 1’s
child. She reported Foster Parent 1’s friend also swore at Youth A.
She reported she found out about this information from Youth A
during a parenting time visit and she reported the information to
Program Manager of the agency. She reported she does not know
the outcome or what happened afterwards. BM reported she
would like not to be ignored by this agency, transfer to another
agency, and would like this agency to start addressing
reunification with her about Youth A and Youth B who are in two
different foster care placements at this time.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed via TEAMS on
8/15/2025. She reported she has been responding and
communicating with BM directly because she and Foster Care
Worker receive many emails from BM daily. She reported the
agency has investigated each complaint BM has brought to the
agency’s attention about Youth A and Youth B’s foster home
placements. She reported that the agency is supportive of BM
when BM allows it. She reported that BM makes recordings of
every meeting and conversation between Foster Care Worker and
PM without permission. PM reported she communicates with BM
on a consistent basis and tries to provide her with any type of
resources she requests or needs. She reported Foster Parent 2
was informed to notify the agency regarding any incident that
occurs with Youth A and Youth B prior to contacting BM first.
PM reported she and FCW were not aware of Youth A’s
behavioral issues in school. She reported the school did not report
any behaviors to the agency. She reported she and Foster Care
Worker learned of behavioral issues in the school from BM. She
reported BM told the agency that she was informed of the
information by Foster Parent 2. PM reported if she had known of
this issue she would have followed up with the school and
informed BM. PM reported after learning of behavioral issues
from BM she informed the Foster Care Worker to follow up with
the issue with the school to see if Youth A was still having this
issue.
PM reported the agency completed an investigation on Foster
Parent 1’s home regarding allegations of Foster Parent 1 being an
alcoholic, smoking marijuana in the home and Foster Parent 1’s
son hitting Youth A. PM reported upon completion of the
investigation, she and Foster Care Worker informed BM of the
3

outcome. She reported BM was dissatisfied with the outcome and
made sure PM and Foster Care Worker knew it.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed 10/14/25, via
telephone and documentation due to previous commitments
and not being available. FCW repeated similar information
reported by Program Manager. She added she was assigned to
the case on 3/14/25. FCW reported she works with BM on a
weekly basis, and the working relationship is as good as it can be.
She reported she does her best to explain and provide clarification
to BM of her role as the caseworker. She reported she is aware
that BM is not pleased with their agency, so she tries to meet BM
at her level and use what she has learned about BM to improve
the working relationship. FCW reported BM mentioned she wants
to communicate with her via email along with her supervisor
included on the email and she obliges, which appears to make BM
satisfied.
FCW reported she followed up with the school regarding Youth
A’s behaviors of him hitting other youths in the school. She
reported Youth A’s teacher reported there are no behavioral
problems to report on for Youth A. The teacher reported his
attendance is great and he gets along with his peers. FCW
reported she reported this information to BM as well documented
this within her social work contacts in MiSACWIS.
FCW reported for reunification to occur BM needs a psychological
evaluation and foster care supportive visitation. She reported BM
has taken parenting classes and she is monitoring BM’s
compliance with ongoing mental health, domestic violence, and
her probation. FCW reported that the court requested additional
information about the parenting class curriculum, and parenting
children with special needs. FCW reported that BM only provides
the agency with complete certificates.
Foster Parent 1 was interviewed on 8/25/25, via telephone.
She reported she was Youth A’s Foster Care from 3/14/25 until
5/1/25. She reported Youth A was sweet and she enjoyed being
his caregiver. She reported she was Youth A’s original foster
parent when he first came into care. She reported that FCW
asked her to be a respite care provider for Youth A since she
knew Youth A and she was once his foster parent who Youth A
was familiar with, and she agreed. Foster Parent 1 reported she
became a respite care provider for Foster Parent 2 when Youth A
was placed in the home of Foster Parent 2 for a couple of
weekends due to Foster Parent 2 becoming overwhelmed with
4

Youth A’s behaviors. She reported it was never intended for Youth
A to remain in her home; this was a temporary placement. She
reported due to complaints filed on her home, she no longer
wanted to be involved with Youth A. She reported the allegations
made on her home were not substantiated.
Foster Parent 2 was interviewed on 8/25/25, via telephone.
She reported Youth A was placed with her from 5/1/25 until
8/21/25. She said Youth A was moved due to complaints made
on her home about mistreating Youth A, and other allegations.
She reported there were no violations found on her home. Foster
Parent 2 reported she did not have a relationship with Youth A,
but she made sure he was well taken care of. She reported Youth
A was into himself and that he could be very manipulative and
brought much drama into her home and she requested for respite
care for Youth A on weekends. Foster Parent 2 reported if Youth
A did not get his way he would state, “I will just go to the next
placement.” Foster Parent 2 reported Youth A would rather go to
different placements opposed to going home to his BM. She
reported that she and BM got along well and she shared
information with BM about Youth A and Youth B’s behaviors and
their wellbeing. She reported when Youth A and Youth B were
placed in her home she talked with BM almost daily. She reported
if anything occurred with Youth A and Youth B, she would share
this information with BM and then with the agency. Foster Parent
2 reported that the Program Manager informed her to bring all
information to the agency first regarding Youth A and Youth B’s
behaviors, and any illness. Foster Parent 2 reported she and BM
had an understanding, and they were respectful towards one
another.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s MiSACWIS case record was reviewed. He is a
temporary court ward. Youth A was placed nine times; four
with his Maternal Grandmother, one with Foster Parent 1,
one with Foster Parent 2, one with BM, and he had one
AWOL from 3/7/25 to 3/8/25.
• Youth B’s MiSACWIS case record was reviewed. He is a
temporary court ward. Youth B was placed nine times. He
was placed three different times with Maternal
Grandmother; one time with a different relative for a short
period of time from 3/10/25 until 3/14/25, in the BM home
from 1/10/25 until 1/30/25, Foster Parent 2 one time and
three times in different licensed/unlicensed foster homes.
• Team Decision Meetings (TDM) and Family Team
Meetings (FTM) dated from 7/22/24, 7/29/24, 8/6/24,
5

4/4/25, 4/24/25,6/4/25 and 8/18/25. BM, FCW and/or
Program Manager were in attendance of these meetings.
• Outcome of Maternal Grandmother complaint allegations
and Foster Parent 1 complaint allegations. All of the
allegations had no rule violations. The outcomes were
discussed with BM by FCW and Program Manager.
• Social work contacts for Youth A and Youth B’s cases.
Information detailed face to face contacts with BM and the
conversations that took place amongst FCW and Program
Manager. Conversations included behaviors of Youth A and
Youth B, medical appointments and their well-being. The
communication was consistent and informed weekly in
case contacts, home visits, TDM’s FTM’s, emails and
parenting visits.
• Court report dated 9/11/25 for BM was reviewed. The
Court report states the following: BM’s motion to withdraw
plea and motion for request for reunification and/or Families
First Program are denied. After conducting dispositional
hearings regarding the legal father and BM, the court
adopts the Parent Agency Treatment Plans (PATPs) with
no amendments as to legal father and BM. BM provided
documentation parenting class certificates of completion,
participation in mental health counseling, and a psychiatric
medical review. BM is to provide documentation of the
topics that were taught in these classes for DHHS and the
Court to review to determine if these classes meet the
goals of the PATP. BM is to also provide additional
documentation regarding her last psychological evaluation
for the Court to determine if
this evaluation meets the goals of the PATP.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation reviewed, the evidence
supports that active communication is provided to Biological
Mother by way of agency meetings, TDM's, FTM's, daily emails,
court hearings and home visits from the FCW and Program
Manager.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
Section • (3) The agency shall document all the following in the
Description child’s record before a change of placement occurs:
• (f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
6

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not maintaining appropriate communication with
respondent parent regarding change in placements.
Investigation Biological mother (BM) was interviewed on 8/13/2025, via
telephone. BM reported that she requested from Program
Manager and Foster Care Worker to inform her immediately of
Youth A and Youth B’s movement from one placement to another
and their behaviors. She reported she learned Youth A was
placed with Foster Parent 1, who is an alcoholic from Foster
Parent 2. She reported she was not notified of the placement
change from the agency. BM reported it was not in the best
interest of Youth A and Youth B to be placed with an alcoholic,
and she did not agree to the change in placement. BM reported
she was not notified nor was there a team meeting for this
placement.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed via TEAMS on
8/15/2025. She reported she and FCW discussed the allegations
of Foster Parent 1 with BM. She reported BM was not satisfied
with the results. PM reported there were no rule violations on
Foster Parent 1, but Foster Parent 1 was given a safety plan. PM
reported Youth A was placed with Foster Parent 1 as a temporary
placement. She explained that TDM's are not held for respites as
it is a temporary placement change and not meant to be
permanent. This is something that is offered to caregivers to help
with maintaining a placement. PM reported caregivers
often take advantage of respite care when they are unable to take
youths out of town, have an event that the youths cannot attend,
need a break, etc.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed 10/14/25, via
telephone and documentation due to previous commitments
and not being available. She reported she did not discuss
Youth A going to Foster Parent 1’s as a temporary respite
placement. She reported she discussed the respite with Youth A
who is old enough and cognizant of his own circumstances who
said he was excited to go with Foster Parent 1 for the weekend.
FCW reported when BM learned of this information, she was
upset and reminded her and PM of the issues that Foster Parent 1
had a complaint on previously. She reported she informed BM the
allegations were not substantiated, and Foster Parent 1 had a
safety planned in place.
7

FCW admitted she should have shared the placement move with
BM and moving forward she will do so. FCW explained at the time
she did not see the placement move affecting BM’s and her plan
for reunification. FCW reported the paperwork involved with
respites and replacements can be time consuming so that does
not leave much time for her to stop and think that she should
inform BM of the respite placement. She said moving forward,
she will make sure she includes any change of placements with
birth parents.
FCW reported that Youth A is currently placed with his Maternal
Grandmother as requested by BM. Maternal Grandmother
previous allegations were not substantiated; therefore, this
placement is safe, appropriate, and BM was notified of the
placement change by the FCW and PM prior to the change. BM
approved of this placement.
Documents Reviewed:
• Safety Plan for Foster Parent 1 dated 4/23/25, by the
agency Licensing Worker and signed 4/30/25, by Foster
Parent 1. The plan states that Foster Parent 1 will follow
the licensing rules and agency policy regarding the use of
substances including smoking cigarettes, alcohol and
marijuana use. Foster Parent 1 agrees to safeguard
substances as discussed with the agency. Foster Parent 1
agrees to smoke substances outside of the home. Foster
Parent 1 will keep marijuana in a locked box in her locked
bedroom and alcohol locked in a cabinet in her locked
bedroom. Foster Parent 1 understands and agrees not to
smoke marijuana in front of youths and only outside of the
home. Foster Parent 1 agrees and understands to keep all
substances out of the reach of youths at all time. Foster
Parent 1 agrees to not drive at least 8 hours after usage
and to contact the agency for any emergencies.
• Special Investigation report of Foster Parent 1 initiated
4/17/25 and closed 5/22/25. Recommendation license
remains unchanged, no violations established. Safety Plan
implemented.
• Special Investigation of Maternal Grandmother initiated
8/8/25, by DHHS. There were no findings.
8

Analysis Program Manager reported TDM's are not held for respites as it is
a temporary placement change and not meant to be permanent
placement change. Foster Care Worker stated she did not
discuss Youth A going to Foster Parent 1’s as a temporary respite
placement. She reported she discussed the respite placement
(Foster Parent 1) with Youth A. Although original placement was
intended for respite, Youth A stayed with Foster Parent 1 for
almost two months and became a change of placement versus a
respite placement. FCW did not notify BM of the change in
placement.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12413
Section Medical and dental care policy
Description • (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
• (b) The provision of emergency medical, surgical,
and dental care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency is not maintaining appropriate communication with
respondent parent regarding child medical issues.
Investigation Biological mother (BM) was interviewed on 8/13/2025, via
telephone. She reported that Youth B had a seizure on 8/2/2025,
and she was informed of this when Foster Parent 2 called her and
stated Youth B was having a seizure and to meet her at the
hospital. BM reported Foster Care Worker and Program Manager
did not inform her Youth B had a seizure and was taken to the
hospital. She reported when she asked them about Youth B being
transported to the hospital, Program Manager told her the agency
assumed Foster Parent 2 had already informed her. BM reported
she felt this was an inappropriate answer coming from
professionals.
BM reported Youth B has appointments to see his pediatric
neurology specialist on 8/5/25, due to his brain bleed that
occurred in February 2025. She reported Youth B missed this
appointment and BM was not given a reason why the appointment
was missed. BM explained Youth B’s brain bleed was
unexplained, and she had no idea how it occurred while he was in
her care. She reported in a recent parenting time visit with Youth
9

A; he shared with her that he caused the brain bleed of Youth B.
She reported Youth A told her he got up in the middle of the night
when everyone was sleeping, went into Youth B’s bedroom,
picked him up and dropped him on the floor. Youth A told BM he
picked Youth B up from the floor and placed him back in his crib.
BM reported she was unaware of this because she never heard
Youth B crying or noise coming from Youth B’s bedroom. BM
reported she immediately informed FCW who was monitoring the
parenting time visit. No additional information was reported
regarding this incident.
BM reported another appointment for Youth B’s neurologist was
scheduled for 8/11/2025, and Youth B was very late for this
appointment, but the neurologists did see him.
FCW was interviewed 10/14/25, via telephone. She reported
BM called the agency to discuss Youth B having a seizure before
she was able to inform BM. She reported Youth B has been
placed in the home of Foster Parent 2 since 5/1/2025. Foster
Parent 2 is fictive kin who BM is friends with. She reported Foster
Parent 2 shares information about everything that happens with
Youth A or Youth B with BM before calling the agency. She said
the agency had a conversation with Foster Parent 2 regarding
reporting information/incidents to the agency regarding
placements in her home prior to sharing with foster parents.
FCW stated anytime there are any type of medical issues, BM is
informed as soon as they hear of a medical issue and
appointments.
Program Manager (PM) was interviewed via TEAMS on
8/15/25. PM reported similar information as FCW, in that anytime
there is any type of medical issue, BM is informed as soon as
possible when they hear of a medical issue and she is informed
on appointments.
Foster Parent 2 (FP2) was interviewed on 8/25/25, via
telephone. She reported she has known BM for a long time.
Foster Parent 2 reported Youth B was always sick and that she
assumed a lot of his sickness came from attending day care. She
reported he catches colds regularly. FP 2 reported Youth B had
hand/foot/mouth disease, walking pneumonia, and seizures. She
reported she shared the information with BM and the agency
when he was sick or having a fever. She reported that Youth B
attends his medical appointments.
10

DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth B’s medical passport in MiSCWIS was reviewed.
Youth B had numerous doctor appointments such as
regular well-being checkup, dental appointments, MRI’s,
EEG, neurologist and hematology appointments. The
medical passport showed these appointments were kept
and reported if follow up was needed. The medical
passport did not show that Youth B was on any
medications.
• Social Work Contacts (SWC) of Youth B’s case. FCW
entered detailed medical contacts in the SWC’s of Youth B
in MiSACWIS. BM name was mentioned in every contact
as knowing the medical updates for Youth B.
Analysis Based on interviews and documentation reviewed, there is
insufficient evidence to support a rule violation as BM was made
aware of all medical information from the agency for Youth B.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation was conducted regarding allegations that Orchards Children's Services failed to properly communicate with the biological mother (BM) about her children in foster care. The investigation found that while communication regarding service plans and medical issues was adequate and no violation was established in those areas, the agency did violate policy by failing to notify the BM of a placement change when a child's temporary respite stay turned into a nearly two-month placement without her knowledge. The violation points to an agency oversight, but the report indicates the facility is generally in compliance aside from this specific failure.
